Article Title: Julian Edelman calls out NFL‚Äôs ‚Äòcheap‚Äô playoff pay: Even Tom Brady got screwed
Article Text:

How NFL Contracts ACTUALLY Work | Games With Names

Brock Purdy's big contract strikes a chord with Edelman

When fans watch NFL stars like Tom Brady or Patrick Mahomes dominate in the playoffs, most assume they're pocketing millions for every throw, every touchdown, every win. But as former New England Patriots wide receiver Julian Edelman recently explained, that assumption couldn‚Äôt be further from the truth.Appearing on the Games with Names podcast, Edelman peeled back the curtain on how playoff compensation works in the NFL. Unlike the regular season, where paychecks are determined by massive contracts and performance bonuses, postseason pay is a fixed structure. Everyone‚Äîfrom the franchise quarterback to the backup kicker‚Äîearns the same per game, regardless of their regular-season salary.‚ÄúFor the first round you‚Äôd get like twenty grand, twenty-five grand to the winner,‚Äù Edelman shared. ‚ÄúThe next round, you‚Äôd get like an additional thirty grand. We would get the first-round bye, do the same amount of work, and not get paid. It was only twenty grand, but I was making like one hundred grand at the time.‚ÄùThat pay gap becomes even more jarring when you look at elite quarterbacks like Brady and Mahomes. ‚ÄúTom Brady usually gets $2 million a game,‚Äù Edelman explained. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs going to play for $20,000. Patrick Mahomes is getting $50 million a year, and now he‚Äôs getting twenty grand, thirty grand‚Ä¶ Same as the long snapper.‚ÄùThe league‚Äôs playoff pay system, though controversial among players, does reinforce one unique NFL value: team unity. ‚ÄúEveryone in the organization earns the same amount of money for playoff games,‚Äù Edelman pointed out. For trainers, assistant coaches, and lesser-known players, the extra checks are meaningful, even if they seem like a rounding error for top-tier stars.Edelman also took a moment to celebrate 49ers quarterback Brock Purdy‚Äôs new five-year, $265 million deal. As a fellow seventh-round pick, Edelman knows the grind of proving oneself.‚ÄúAs a former player, you always like to see guys get paid,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúEspecially a guy that went his route. Now he‚Äôs making $54 million per year.‚ÄùAlso Read: Tom Brady risks it all at Indy 500: NFL legend trades football fame for 200 mph thrill ride with Jimmie Johnson Purdy‚Äôs new contract averages nearly $3 million per week‚Äîa staggering rise from the $2.6 million total he earned in his first three seasons. His story is a reminder that in the NFL, humble beginnings can lead to massive paydays‚Äîjust not in the playoffs.

Article Title: Why dragging out the Aaron Rodgers saga could damage Steelers' playoff hopes beyond repair
Article Text:
Steelers‚Äô patience with Aaron Rodgers may backfire unless they make a bold quarterback decision now (Getty Images)

Why are the Steelers STILL Waiting on Aaron Rodgers? | James Skrmetta Reacts

As the NFL world waits for Aaron Rodgers‚Äô next move, the Pittsburgh Steelers remain in a holding pattern. Team president Art Rooney II recently told ESPN that they plan to wait "a little while longer" for Rodgers‚Äô decision‚Äîa familiar stance he echoed more than a month ago. But beneath the surface of patience lies a deeper reality: Rodgers to Pittsburgh might make for compelling headlines, but it‚Äôs a move that could derail more than it could deliver.On paper, Aaron Rodgers signing with the Steelers would be ‚Äúabsolute cinema.‚Äù Imagine a future Hall of Famer attempting to resurrect his career with a storied franchise starved for playoff relevance. The Steelers, after all, have gone eight years without a postseason victory. They finished 10-3 last season only to collapse down the stretch, losing five straight‚Äîincluding a bruising playoff exit against Baltimore where they allowed 299 rushing yards. The logic? Plug Rodgers into an already competitive roster, add a receiver he‚Äôs comfortable with, and make a deep postseason run.It sounds like a Hollywood script. But the NFL isn‚Äôt scripted, and this move comes with layers of complication.Rodgers‚Äô ability to turn a game on its head hasn‚Äôt vanished entirely‚Äîhis touchdown pass to Garrett Wilson last season served as a dazzling reminder. Yet moments of brilliance were overshadowed by inconsistency and visible signs of decline. The same quarterback who delivered an MVP campaign in 2021 looked hesitant and off-rhythm in stretches last year. A mid-season loss to Pittsburgh saw him picked off twice by then-rookie Beanie Bishop Jr. , a sign of how erratic his play can be under pressure.And let‚Äôs not forget, this is a quarterback entering his age-42 season, fresh off a major Achilles injury. His trademark mobility‚Äîthe element that made him lethal‚Äîhas faded. Steelers fans saw how Ben Roethlisberger‚Äôs final seasons unfolded: the body slowed, the offense stagnated, and a living legend gradually became a liability. Rodgers, it seems, is on a similar trajectory.Rodgers isn‚Äôt just a quarterback‚Äîhe‚Äôs a media magnet. Every appearance on the Pat McAfee Show will make headlines. Every sideline interaction will be scrutinized. For a franchise known for its discipline and unity under Mike Tomlin, the Rodgers spotlight might bring more distraction than direction.Then there's the impact on internal development. Young talents like Will Howard‚Äîa promising college national champion‚Äîand Mason Rudolph, who ended last season on a high note, deserve a real opportunity. Bringing in Rodgers essentially pushes both down the pecking order, sending a message that name recognition trumps offseason effort and chemistry. That‚Äôs not just demoralizing‚Äîit‚Äôs destabilizing.Even if Aaron Rodgers returns to form, Pittsburgh would still need a lot to go right. The offensive line, though improving, is young. The receiving corps lacks a proven No. 2 option to pair with DK Metcalf. And defensively, the unit that crumbled late last season must take a major step forward.Let‚Äôs be honest‚Äî2025 is shaping up to be a transitional season. With a treasure chest of draft capital in 2026, the Steelers are likely viewing this year as an experiment: a chance to test the roster‚Äôs ceiling before going all-in on a long-term quarterback solution. In that light, signing Rodgers becomes more of a stunt than a strategy.There‚Äôs no denying Rodgers brings intrigue, experience, and the potential for one last great chapter. But the Steelers are chasing stability, not spectacle. A franchise that has prided itself on consistency and calculated decisions doesn‚Äôt need to gamble on a quarterback whose best days are behind him‚Äîno matter how legendary he is.In the end, the Steelers‚Äô path forward likely lies not in the past greatness of Aaron Rodgers, but in the untapped potential of the next generation.Also Read: Should Tom Brady unretire to lead Team USA in flag football at the 2028 Olympics? Fans manifest GOAT's return for one last time
Article Summary: Pittsburgh Steelers president Art Rooney II said they plan to wait "a little while longer" for Aaron Rodgers' decision. The Steelers have gone eight years without a postseason victory. Rodgers brings intrigue, experience and the potential for one last great chapter. But the Steelers are chasing stability, not spectacle.

Article Title: IPL 2025: Ishan Kishan and Pat Cummins dent RCB's top-two hopes

Now, a win for PBKS and Mumbai Indians, who have 17 and 16 points respectively, will push them even more behind in the race for top-two.
Article Summary: Sunrisers Hyderabad beat Royal Challengers Bengaluru by 42 runs. Ishan Kishan top scored with 94 from 48 deliveries for SRH. Virat Kohli and Phil Salt top scored for RCB with 62 runs each.

Article Title: Delhi Results 2025: 'LinkedIn Lessons' from Brand BJP's win and Brand AAP's loss
Article Text:
AAP: From Disruptor to Establishment to Decline



AAP was the ultimate political startup‚Äîthe kind that raises Series A, B, and C funding at record speed, becomes a unicorn, and then implodes under its own weight. It was supposed to be the alternative to traditional politics, the fresh face in a crowded market, a party that rejected caste, religion, and dynasty-driven politics.

But somewhere along the way, it stopped being a startup and started behaving like an old-school corporate giant‚Äîbloated, bureaucratic, and overconfident.

1) From Lean & Agile to Bureaucratic & Slow

AAP started with hyperlocal engagement, grassroots activism, and direct voter outreach‚Äîthe political equivalent of a D2C brand shaking up a legacy market.

Over time, it became centralized and top-heavy, with decision-making confined to a handful of leaders. MLAs became inaccessible, the leadership became distant, and ground-level mobilization weakened. No succession planning. Kejriwal remained the sole face of the party, and there was no second-rung leadership strong enough to carry the brand forward. It failed to expand beyond Delhi and Punjab‚Äîdespite trying in Goa, Gujarat, and Karnataka. The inability to scale beyond its original USP made it a regional player rather than a national force.

It failed to expand beyond Delhi and Punjab‚Äîdespite trying in Goa, Gujarat, and Karnataka. The inability to scale beyond its original USP made it a regional player rather than a national force. The result? Voters saw it as just another party, not the disruptor it once was.

2) A Reputation Built on Ethics, Lost to Scandals

AAP built its brand on fighting corruption‚Äîbut its own leadership got embroiled in one of the biggest scandals of its time, the liquor policy scam.

Manish Sisodia, Sanjay Singh, and even Kejriwal himself faced corruption allegations, undoing years of anti-corruption positioning.

The Sheesh Mahal controversy‚Äîwhere Kejriwal‚Äôs residence was allegedly renovated with ‚Çπ45 crore of taxpayer money‚Äîcompletely shattered the ‚Äúhumble leader‚Äù narrative.

AAP‚Äôs response? Defensive, aggressive, and dismissive. Instead of damage control, it doubled down on denial‚Äîa classic PR blunder.

The perception shift was swift and brutal‚Äîfrom ‚Äúanti-corruption warriors‚Äù to just another power-hungry political entity.

3) Ignoring the Middle-Class Voter That Built Its Base

AAP was originally the party of the middle class‚Äîfrustrated taxpayers who wanted clean governance and economic relief.

Over time, its focus shifted to freebies and populist policies, leaving the middle class feeling ignored.

BJP stepped in at the right time‚Äîoffering tax reliefs, infrastructure promises, and a governance model that reassured middle-class voters.

Takeaway ? A business (or party) that forgets its core customer will eventually lose them.

4) Blaming External Factors Instead of Owning Failures

For 10 years, AAP blamed the Centre, the LG, and opposition parties for everything.

The ‚Äúvictim card‚Äù was effective in the early years but wore thin by 2025‚Äîvoters expected governance, not excuses.

BJP flipped this weakness into an advantage, promising that with a BJP-led government, there would be no Centre-state conflicts, leading to ‚Äúseamless governance.‚Äù

The narrative changed from ‚ÄúAAP vs. BJP‚Äù to ‚ÄúAAP vs. Results.‚Äù Lesson? Leaders who constantly shift blame instead of delivering solutions lose credibility.

5) Strategic Missteps and Lack of Political Alliances

AAP contested separately from Congress, which led to a split in the anti-BJP vote.

Rahul Gandhi‚Äôs direct attacks on Kejriwal made matters worse‚ÄîAAP was getting hit from both sides.

Internal conflicts weakened the party further. Atishi and Saurabh Bharadwaj were seen as Kejriwal‚Äôs successors, but there was no clear transition strategy.

BJP: A Masterclass in Strategic Adaptation

BJP‚Äôs 2025 win in Delhi was not a Modi-centric sweep but a well-calibrated organizational comeback. After a lackluster 2024 Lok Sabha performance (by their standards), the party realized it had become too dependent on a single leader.

performance (by their standards), the party realized it had become too dependent on a single leader. Unlike AAP, BJP adapted, restructured, and executed flawlessly.

1) Moving Beyond Modi Dependency

BJP understood that Delhi‚Äôs electorate needed a more localized approach.

Instead of making the election about Modi, it focused on governance, urban issues, and direct voter engagement.

No CM face? It didn‚Äôt matter. The party projected collective leadership instead of relying on one individual.

By decentralizing its campaign, BJP looked more stable and future-ready.

2) Adopting AAP‚Äôs Own Strategies Against It

BJP neutralized AAP‚Äôs welfare advantage‚Äîpromising free electricity, continued subsidies, and additional financial support for women.

Middle-class tax reliefs were announced just before the elections, ensuring they won over voters that AAP had neglected.

The manifesto focused on real urban issues‚Äîpollution control, traffic congestion, and infrastructure‚Äîexactly what AAP had failed to address convincingly.

Lesson? The best way to beat a competitor is to adopt their strengths while exposing their weaknesses.

3) Letting Congress Do The Attacking



BJP didn‚Äôt need to attack AAP aggressively‚ÄîRahul Gandhi and Congress did that for them.

By letting AAP and Congress fight it out, BJP consolidated its voter base while the opposition split.

AAP‚Äôs credibility suffered more because the attacks came from within the anti-BJP camp.

A strategic win, without unnecessary effort.

4) A Disciplined, Focused, and Well-Executed Campaign

BJP stayed on message, focusing on corruption, governance, and economic stability.

The campaign was structured and well-planned, unlike AAP‚Äôs which seemed reactive and disorganized.

The promise to investigate AAP‚Äôs corruption cases resonated with voters, reinforcing BJP‚Äôs stance on accountability.

In business terms? BJP had a clear marketing strategy, strong brand positioning, and flawless execution.

5) Final Takeaways

Adaptability is key. BJP recalibrated after its 2024 Lok Sabha setbacks, while AAP remained stagnant.

Brand trust is fragile. AAP built its image on honesty but lost credibility due to scandals and mismanagement.

Execution matters more than rhetoric. BJP delivered a disciplined, well-structured campaign.

Leadership succession planning is critical. AAP failed to build second-line leadership, while BJP showcased organizational depth.

Voters reward governance, not excuses. After a decade in power, AAP‚Äôs blame game no longer worked.

Politics, like business, rewards those who adapt, execute, and deliver.

Ah, another election, another flood of LinkedIn wisdom posts‚Äîwhere every poll result is a "case study," every political leader is a "CEO," and every campaign is an "MBA-level lesson in leadership." Some call it democracy, but on LinkedIn, it‚Äôs all about business jargon and corporate analogies.So, let‚Äôs break this down the LinkedIn way.BJP, on the other hand, had a structured, disciplined campaign with clear messaging and no internal rifts. In politics and business, a divided team rarely wins.
Article Summary: AAP started with hyperlocal engagement, grassroots activism, and direct voter outreach. It became centralized and top-heavy, with decision-making confined to a handful of leaders. The inability to scale beyond its original USP made it a regional player rather than a national force. Voters saw it as just another party, not the disruptor it once was.

Article Title: A new era dawns at Roland Garros: No Rafael Nadal, slumping Iga Swiatek and no obvious favourites
Article Text:
Carlos Alcaraz (L) and Coco Gauff (R) are two of the contenders to lift the French Open title. (Getty Images/AP)

For many years, the French Open had a predictability attached to it. For better or for worse, Rafael Nadal in the men‚Äôs field and Iga Swiatek in the women‚Äôs field were the safe bets. Both had stellar records to justify that billing. Nadal won 14 titles at Roland Garros (2005-2008; 2010-2014; 2017-2020; 2022) while Swiatek triumphed four years in a row (2020, 2022, 2023 and 2024). The Spaniard has dominated the red clay more than any one in the history of the sport and a 112-4 record is a clear indication of it. Still not convinced? The 14 times he reached the final, he won them all.Swiatek‚Äôs reign in women's singles has been for a shorter time period and yet has been equally impressive with four titles in five years, including the last three. Among the active players, she has the best win percentage at Roland Garros (35-2; 94.6%) and she triumphed in 2020 without dropping a set.Now, as the French Open begins on Sunday, May 25, there are no crystal clear favourites as before. 38-year-old Nadal has retired and will be on Philippe Chatrier Court only for a farewell ceremony on Sunday. He bowed out last year with his injury-hampered body not co-operating to the grind of the sport anymore. His final French Open appearance was a defeat to Alexander Zverev and Roland Garros adieu came a few weeks later at the Paris Olympics, losing to Novak Djokovic in singles, followed by doubles alongside Carlos Alcaraz.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs ... 20 different people that you wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if they end up winning the tournament,‚Äù said USA‚Äôs Madison Keys, whose first major trophy came at the Australian Open in January. ‚ÄúPart of it is because we‚Äôve kind of lost some of our legends, obviously. Like, there‚Äôs no longer Serena Williams in every draw, where you just assume she‚Äôs going to win."Poland‚Äôs Swiatek took over that mantle from Serena, at least in Paris, for the past five years. That cannot be said this time around.Ever since clinching the title last year, she‚Äôs not reached a final let alone win a tournament. The fifth seed has had a less than flattering clay court swing in preparation. She lost in the quarterfinals of Stuttgart, was hammered with a double breadstick by Coco Gauff in Madrid and an equally dismal show against Danielle Collins in Rome.Off the court, Swiatek has had an equally trying time. In a doping case, Swiatek was essentially cleared but did serve an oddly timed suspension.That brings us to the ‚ÄòD‚Äô word which has gripped the sport more than on-court tennis. Swiatek now down to World No. 5 - trailing Aryna Sabalenka, Gauff, Jessica Pegula and Jasmine Paolini - and men‚Äôs World No. 1 Jannik Sinner have both been punished in different and equally peculiar ways. The Italian served a three-month ban earlier this year despite being cleared of wrongdoing by the sport‚Äôs governing body.After winning the Australian Open, Sinner reached a deal with the World Anti-Doping Agency, which appealed against the 23-year-old‚Äôs exoneration. It meant he won his third major title in Melbourne, went into a three-month hiatus, only to return for the Italian Open in Rome where he finished runner-up to Carlos Alcaraz.Alcaraz was asked about the complexity of the doping world, taking Max Purcell‚Äôs ban as an example, which he said ‚Äúsounded like Chinese‚Äù. But what doesn‚Äôt sound like a foreign language is the desire to win a fifth major and second in a row in Paris. His muscle issues in both legs seemed to have become a thing of the past if the Rome final was any indication. Yet, despite his similarities and wish to pick up the mantle from Nadal, he is not a lock-in like his idol.That brings us to other contenders such as three-time major finalist Alexander Zverev, including making the last-four at Roland Garros in the last four straight editions. The inconsistent German‚Äôs best showing in the tune-up events was the title in Munich.Speaking of titles, Novak Djokovic, seeking his 25th major once again, clinched his 100th ATP trophy in Geneva, joining a list that is led by Jimmy Connors and Roger Federer. His first title since winning the gold medal at the Paris Olympics last year only faintly masks his three-match losing streak before it.‚ÄúKind of [a] new reality for me, I have to say. You know, trying to win a match or two, not really thinking about getting far in the tournament. It‚Äôs a completely different feeling from what I had in 20-plus years of professional tennis, so it‚Äôs kind of a challenge for me, mentally, to really face these kinds of sensations on the court, going out early now, regularly,‚Äù Djokovic said after an opening exit in Madrid.‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs, I guess, the circle of life and the career. Eventually, it was going to happen. ... Grand Slams is where I really want to play the best tennis,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure if I‚Äôll be able to do that in Roland-Garros, but I‚Äôll do my best.‚ÄùOn the women‚Äôs side, the field is open amid Swiatek‚Äôs unprecedented slump. The variety of tune-up champions tells the story - Jessica Pegula (Charleston), Jelena Ostapenko (Stuttgart), Aryna Sabalenka (Madrid) and Jasmine Paolini (Rome). Paolini became the eighth different player to reach a WTA 1000 final this season before pocketing her biggest career title.Sabalenka briefly dropped off from her best form after a surprise Australian Open final loss to Madison Keys before bouncing back with the Miami and Madrid Open titles."I got really hungry and angry -- angry in a good way and I think at the end, the Australian Open final pushed me to work even harder," she told the WTA."(It) kind of explained to me that you have to really work hard in finals and you have to earn your victories. It was a good push for me."Coco Gauff's first final appearances in Madrid and Rome have helped her return to a career-high of World No. 2, giving her the second seeding for Paris. The 21-year-old, a former Roland Garros runner-up, is waiting for her first title since last year's WTA Finals."Hopefully I can get to the final in Roland Garros and maybe the 'Third time lucky' thing is a real thing," Gauff said after losing to Paolini in Rome.There are multiple dark horses on the WTA Tour to clinch their maiden Grand Slam title, none more impressive than Mirra Andreeva.In February, she made history as the youngest-ever WTA 1000 champion in Dubai, then followed it up with an even more remarkable victory at Indian Wells.Now 18, Andreeva is a strong contender in Paris, aspiring to become the youngest Grand Slam singles champion since Maria Sharapova at Wimbledon in 2004. She showcased her credentials on clay by reaching the Roland Garros semi-finals last year and the quarter-finals in Madrid and Rome this season.Another one to be careful of is China‚Äôs 22-year-old Zheng Qinwen who will be hoping to replicate the form that took her to Olympic gold at Roland Garros last summer.
Article Summary: Rafael Nadal won 14 titles at Roland Garros between 2005-2008 and 2010-2014. Iga Swiatek won four years in a row at the French Open between 2020 and 2024. Nadal has retired and will be on Philippe Chatrier Court only for a farewell ceremony on Sunday.

Nair's 27-ball innings featured two sixes and five fours, proving crucial in the run chase.The chase began positively with KL Rahul, serving as impact substitute, scoring 35 off 21 balls, and stand-in captain Faf du Plessis contributing 23 off 15 balls. They established a quick 55-run partnership in under six overs.Rahul's innings included impressive shots, notably a cover-point boundary off Azmatullah Omarzai and a straight six against Harpreet Brar. However, he fell to Marco Jansen's slow off-cutter, caught by Shashank Singh.Nair, making his return to the Indian Test squad after eight years, started confidently with a six over fine leg off Jansen. Du Plessis's innings ended with a soft dismissal, caught by Priyansh Arya at backward point.Quiz: Who's that IPL player? In the first innings, Punjab Kings posted 206 for eight, powered by Marcus Stoinis 's unbeaten 44 off 16 balls and Shreyas Iyer 's 53 off 34 deliveries. Stoinis's explosive innings included four sixes and three fours.Delhi Capitals, bowling first, found early success when Mustafizur Rahman dismissed Priyansh Arya for 6. The Bangladesh seamer finished with figures of 3/33.Josh Inglis and Prabhsimran Singh provided early momentum for Punjab Kings before leg-spinner Vipraj Nigam claimed two crucial wickets. Nigam, showing promise for future T20 World Cup consideration, maintained good control throughout his spell.Shreyas Iyer's innings featured aggressive batting, including a six over deep midwicket off Kuldeep Yadav. His stay ended when he hit straight to Mohit Sharma off Kuldeep's bowling.The match saw momentum shifts, with Mukesh Kumar conceding 25 runs in one over. Stoinis capitalized on a dropped catch to score 22 runs off Mohit Sharma's over, helping Punjab Kings post a challenging total.Leg-spinner Praveen Dubey contributed by dismissing Sediqullah Atal for 22 off 16 balls, though he later conceded four consecutive boundaries to Nair as Delhi reached 111 for three in the 11th over.Despite losing Nair at a crucial stage to Brar's bowling, Rizvi's mature batting ensured Delhi Capitals finished their IPL campaign on a winning note. The chase demonstrated Delhi's batting depth and ability to handle pressure situations effectively.The match featured strong performances from both teams' bowlers, with Mustafizur Rahman's strategic angle bowling and Vipraj Nigam's controlled leg-spin standing out. However, the batsmen dominated the contest, with both sides displaying aggressive intent throughout.
Article Summary: Delhi Capitals beat Punjab Kings by six wickets in their final IPL match. Young batsman Sameer Rizvi scored 58 off 25 balls. Karun Nair, recently recalled to the Indian Test team, added 44 runs. Punjab Kings posted 206 in their first innings.
